awd_titl_txt: Dental Microwear and Diet in Live, Wild-Trapped Alouatta    From Costa Rica
awd_abstract_narration: High resolution dental casts can be used to document the pattern of             dental microwear in museum specimens.  The primary objective of                 this proposal is to document not only the pattern of wear, but its              changes and rates over time in a live primate in the wild.                                                                                                      Populations of a New World monkey, Alouatta palliata, which have                been subject to behavioral observation for an extended period will              be trapped and dental impressions taken.  The resulting casts will              be studied via scanning electronmicroscope for wear patterns and                tooth morphology.   Each animal will be re-cast several times                   during the course of the study, allowing for analysis of intra-                 individual change as a function of changing diet.  This work will               allow new insights into the association between diet and toothwear.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine
